body: Three men were killed in separate shootings in Brooklyn on Sunday night. The police found the bodies of a 44-year-old man and another man, both shot numerous times, in an apartment on Kings Highway in East Flatbush around 6 p.m. Neither man was immediately identified by the police. In Bushwick, a third man, Leslie Prosper, 37, was found fatally
title: 3 Men Are Killed In Brooklyn Gunfire

body: FROM dance enclaves in the Bronx to roving, artist-run collectives, showcases for ''emerging choreographers'' -- that fuzzy, mutable category -- are a dime a dozen these days. But this week one of the pioneers, the Fresh Tracks series at Dance Theater Workshop in Chelsea, reaches an important milestone: 500 artists presented, counting a few double
title: DANCE; Memories of a Venerable Showcase

body: Stacks of plastic bags line a wall of Joanne Sawyer's front room. From the jumble of her belongings, she pulls out a child-size pink chair, and bursts into tears. The chair is for her young granddaughters, and it is missing a leg. ''I'm not going to throw it away,'' Ms. Sawyer says. ''We'll find it.'' The chair leg is one of a thousand things that
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Mourning Many Losses, Rebuilding a Sense of Home

body: Ten, 9, 8, 7, 6 nights before Christmas and Santa is in full effect outside the Nextel store on the Fulton Street Mall. He cranks up the skipping soca rhythm on the backing tape and kicks it to the crowds pouring off the buses and trudging with bulging shopping bags down Brooklyn's bustlingest outdoor retail strip. ''Siii-lent night, hooo-ly
title: Step Right Up! Brooklyn Mall Is Oasis and Anomaly

body: GLENDALE has long struggled for postal recognition. In 1979, with the help of an ambitious congresswoman named Geraldine Ferraro, the southwestern Queens communities of Glendale and Ridgewood managed to extricate themselves from a ZIP code shared with nearby Bushwick, a Brooklyn neighborhood then plagued by crime and poverty. But the issue was
title: GLENDALE; In a Sometimes Ignored Neighborhood, First-Class Dreams

body: ''This one,'' Jermaine McKenzie said, pointing to a cauliflower-shaped scar on his right cheek, ''I fell when I was 2.'' Then he took off his jacket to reveal a four-inch mark on his left arm. ''I slipped on a piece of glass,'' he said, adding, ''I have a bunch of others.'' His mother, Georgia Hill, was a nurse and sadly tended to his wounds each
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Learning to Overcome What Life Throws at Them

body: On a Brooklyn street cluttered with dollar stores and cuchifrito stands, New York State's labor commissioner announced on Wednesday a stepped-up enforcement effort against neighborhood businesses that violate the state's wage and hour laws. At a news conference on Knickerbocker Avenue, the main commercial strip in Bushwick, the commissioner, M.
title: Brooklyn Sweep Shows Local Focus in Fight on Labor Violations

title: 205 Schools Accept Plan For Bonus Pay

title: The Chicken and Rice Man

''We're reducing clutter and selling all our stuff on
title: Where Design Heads Double-Dip

body: In a crackdown on some of the worst landlords in New York City, housing officials have identified 200 of the most poorly maintained apartment buildings and are renewing efforts to force owners to repair hazardous conditions. The Department of Housing Preservation and Development compiled a list of 200 buildings that have 27 or more of the most
title: 200 Neglected Buildings Get 4 Months to Improve

author: E-mail: haberman@nytimes.com
body: The bullets were meant for him, but Andre Santana ducked in time. Or maybe the gunmen were just lousy shots. Whatever, he lived and a woman died, having committed the sole crime of walking along the wrong street at the wrong time. By his own account in a Manhattan courtroom, Mr. Santana was a lowlife, in a city with more than its share of lowlifes.
title: NYC; Guns and Random Death: Be Careful Out There

title: Spare Times

body: The police charged a man with manslaughter yesterday in the stabbing death of a man in Brooklyn. The two men had struggled at about 10 p.m. on Monday, in front of 298 12th Street in Park Slope, the police said. The victim, identified as William Rosario, 26, of Ocean Hill, was stabbed once in the chest and was taken to New York Methodist Hospital,
title: Charges in Fatal Stabbing in Brooklyn

body: PERHAPS it was only a matter of time before someone realized that what a certain kind of man wants while getting a haircut is a cold beer -- preferably Chimay. Two graduates of Stanford Graduate School of Business, Sean A. Heywood and Kumi D. Walker, envisioned such an experience a few years ago and have now opened MR., a combination barbershop,
title: For the Guy Who Wants More Than a Little Off the Top

body: Fashioned from a single metal tube bent into a sleek, low-slung frame, Marcel Breuer's Wassily chair was a touchstone of Modernism, a manifestation of the movement's faith in technology, convenience and the promise of a better life. In the artist Iván Navarro's rendition of the chair, the frame is made from three neon tubes in a glowing shade of
title: MATTER; Shock Tactics

body: ''How many of you guys got a hooptee, raise your hand?'' Carlos Caraballo asked his senior auto shop at Automotive High School in Brooklyn. A dozen boys, roughly half the class, raised their hands and began discussing their hooptees. The term is street slang for a cheap, functional car favored by city youths who often tinker tirelessly to make the
title: A High School Under the Hood

body: A Williamsburg man was sentenced yesterday in State Supreme Court to 20 years in prison for raping three women near the Williamsburg and Bushwick Houses projects. The man, Gerard Mitchell, 31, pleaded guilty on Oct. 11 to one count of first-degree rape. He had been charged with attacking three women, ranging in age from 22 to 38, between October
title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Rapist Gets 20-Year Sentence

body: THE Brooklyn real estate market has turned into a bundle of contradictions in recent months. While prices in neighborhoods like Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights soared this summer, so did the number of foreclosures in neighborhoods like Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant. Sorting through these contradictions, buyers are starting to find bargains in a
title: Brooklyn: A Bargain Hunter's Guide

body: The police arrested a Brooklyn man last night in connection with the death of a teenage boy who was shot as he looked out a window of his family's home last week. The man, Sean Gordon, 29, of Bushwick, is suspected of firing the fatal shot, the police said. He faces charges of second-degree murder and criminal possession of a weapon. The boy, Tavin
title: Suspect Is Arrested In Shooting In Brooklyn

body: A teenager was shot in the face about 5 a.m. yesterday as he looked out a third-story window from his family's apartment in Bushwick, the police said. They said the teenager, Tavin Alves Clarke, 16, was in critical condition at Kings County Hospital Center. It was unclear whether he was the intended target or was hit by random gunfire. The police
title: NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Teenager Hurt By Gunfire

body: LIKE most worthwhile relationships, the one that New York City residents forge with their homes is riddled with compromise. But in their relief at stumbling upon a good-enough abode, some apartment seekers overlook (or brush off) the very thing that winds
title: Day and Night

title: Gap in Illness Rates Between Rich and Poor New Yorkers Widens, Study Says

title: Boy Is Hit by 2 Cars and Killed in Brooklyn

title: Catch 25

body: The city's newest team of inspectors won't write tickets or issue fines. They won't harass landlords over leaky pipes or ensure that builders follow safety codes. The target of this team will be the city itself. Yesterday, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg unveiled the Street Conditions Observation Unit, Scout for short, at a news conference in Bushwick,
title: 311 Expands With Scouts to Patrol Streets

body: WITH her fluffy white bath towel, Brenda Gruskin -- taut copper skin, black designer swimsuit, awash in gold jewelry -- claimed a parcel of sun-warmed concrete on the deck of the John Jay Pool on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. ''When I tell people I use city pools, they can't believe it,'' she said, surveying the rectangular gulch of wobbling
title: MY CITY; 52 Ways to Cool Off, And All of Them Free

body: Those were grim days for race relations in New York City, the early 1990s. There were nearly 2,000 murders each year, blacks and whites died in high-profile racial killings, and a riot held a divided Brooklyn neighborhood in thrall for three dangerous nights. On Jan. 9, 1994, another match landed in this tinderbox: a caller reported a burglary at a
title: THE LONG RUN; In a Volatile City, a Stern Line On Race and Politics

title: Spare Times

body: It was the kind of Brooklyn neighborhood where an unmarked car with government plates drew hostile stares, and a badge emblazoned with the words ''immigration officer'' could cause a panic. ''Just keep smiling,'' Tamika Gray, an immigration officer, said aloud to herself as she steered the car under the elevated tracks in Bushwick, meeting the
title: Without Guns or Raids, a Tiny Squad of Officers Homes In on Visa Fraud

body: ONE Monday morning, on the way to her office in the basement of the Montauk Club in Park Slope, Louise Crawford passed a man staring up at a tree. Lingering for a moment, she asked him what was so interesting. It turned out that a yellow-throated songbird known as a Nashville warbler, in its northward migration, had made a pit stop in the
title: Cracker-Barrel 2.0

body: WHEN people ask where I live, I tailor my answer to my audience. If someone with children is asking, I'll answer, ''Park Slope,'' as if I had just won the lottery. If I'm talking to a childless friend who lives somewhere gritty -- say, Bushwick -- I'll duck the question, or mumble that I live near Prospect Park. Lovers and haters of Park Slope are
title: The Park Slope Parent Trap

body: DANCE Full reviews of recent performances: nytimes.com/dance. 'TAP CITY' Dance performances are hard to come by in the middle of the summer, so it seems fitting that tap, which is given scant stage space throughout the year, would take New York by storm every July in the form of ''Tap City,'' Tony Waag's wide-ranging showcase of styles, traditions
title: Dance

body: I AM not one of those people who has a constantly magical time when I travel. If I am outside the country and alone, whether it is Mexico City, Paris or Athens, I will trudge through museums and churches and go to a dumb discothèque, but spend most of my time trying to find toothpaste, and also staring at people, storefronts and logos that make no
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER; International House of Oddities

author: Kareem Fahim and Julie Creswell contributed reporting.
body: With the housing market in decline, financial predators are finding yet another way to take advantage of people who fall behind on their payments. The schemes take various forms and often involve promises to distressed homeowners of cash upfront, free monthly rent and a chance to retain their houses in the long run. But in the process, someone else
title: New Scheme Preys on Desperate Homeowners

body: The covert campaign targeting street art began about seven months ago, with blobs of paint that appeared overnight, obscuring murals and wheat-pasted art on walls in Brooklyn and Lower Manhattan. Arcane messages were pasted at the sites, but it was difficult to ask for an explanation. The author was never identified. Then in November, during a
title: As Street Art Goes Commercial, a Resistance Raises a Real Stink

author: David Brooks is on vacation.
body: The woman was reluctant to let her name be used. She said she had a teenage son and was afraid that he might be harassed by the police. title: OP-ED COLUMNIST; Doubting the Police

title: In the Details Of a Mass Arrest, Two Versions, Worlds Apart

title: URBAN STUDIES | UNWINDING; School's Nearly Out, and Mr. Chips Is Thirsty

title: Not Buying It

Criminal complaints filed against 10 defendants show that the police were concerned about the risk that those arrested would engage in violent or
title: Dispute Over Arrest Pattern At the Puerto Rican Parade

body: A Brooklyn man was fatally shot shortly after 11 a.m. yesterday in a fight on the street in Bushwick, the authorities said. He was pronounced dead at the scene, near the corner of Stanhope Street and Wyckoff Avenue, where, a witness said, he had been shot several
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot And Killed In Street

body: RED HOOK is one of those rare New York neighborhoods where the stars aren't completely obscured by city lights. By late summer, Gita Nandan and Jens Veneman will be able to track them from their bathtub, which they're preparing to relocate to their back deck. And if the gardening gods are beneficent, they'll be able to reach out of the suds to snag
title: HABITATS/Red Hook, Brooklyn; Why Ask for the Moon If You Have the Stars?

title: Arrest of 30 Leads Youths To Organize In Brooklyn

body: The City Council passed a bill yesterday giving the city broad new powers to go after landlords with histories of serious code violations. The bill, known as the Safe Housing Act, would require the Department of Housing Preservation and Development to identify 200 buildings each year with the worst histories of emergency repairs and uncorrected
title: Council Passes Bill Enabling City to Fix Worst Buildings

body: In a move that has greater symbolic significance than mere real estate hopscotch, Galapagos Art Space, the pioneering bar and performing arts space that helped put Williamsburg, Brooklyn, on the cultural map, is moving a few neighborhoods down the East River, to Dumbo. Galapagos, which has played host to a broad array of New York's musicians,
title: Arts Space In Brooklyn To Get New Digs

body: These are small incidents, but they are accumulating by the tens of thousands, and someday New Yorkers are going to be shocked by the power of the anger that these seemingly insignificant incidents have generated. The principal of Bushwick Community High School in Brooklyn told me about a student who was gratuitously insulted by a police officer at
title: Small Incidents Are Creating a Big Problem With the N.Y.P.D.

body: With blasts of disco, tight, flashy costumes and acrobatic flourishes, the skate dancers took over a paved oval in Central Park as rebels. Now, 30 years later, they are part of its establishment, and some of the heavily padded knees are a bit creaky. The music is still loud, but at a legal decibel level, and with the closing of three roller-disco
title: A Little Older and a Bit Creakier, Skaters Boogie On in Central Park

body: New York, a city of renters since immigrants began jamming lodging houses and tenements early in the 19th century, has reached two milestones in homeownership: One in three households now own their dwellings, according to a new analysis of census results. And the number of homes and apartments occupied by their owners has passed one million for the
title: In a City Known for Its Renters, a Record Number Now Own Their Homes

body: No one is paying much attention, but parts of New York City are like a police state for young men, women and children who happen to be black or Hispanic. They are routinely stopped, searched, harassed, intimidated, humiliated and, in many cases, arrested for no good reason. Most black elected officials have joined their white colleagues and the
title: Arrested While Grieving

body: The arrests of about 30 young people on the way to a friend's wake on Monday have set off a wave of anger in Bushwick, Brooklyn, with more than 50 teenagers assembling yesterday to demand an apology, and their teachers saying that the police had unfairly made a target of the arrested youths -- some as young as 13. But the police defended their
title: Apology Is Sought After Arrests of 30 People on the Way to a Slain Teenager's Wake

body: Four people were killed in unrelated cases in less than 12 hours Tuesday night and early yesterday, the police said. The figure is unusually high for a year in which an average of less than one homicide per day has occurred, though Police Commissioner Raymond W. Kelly pointed out yesterday that ''one day doesn't make a trend.'' In the first
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Four Killings In The City In 12 Hours

For an hour, the singer Karen O yelped and shrieked and pranced around a makeshift stage in a paint-splattered gold bodysuit, often wading into the
title: Off The Beaten Beat

body: A man was stabbed and shot to death during a fight outside a club in Bushwick yesterday morning, the police said. The fight occurred shortly after 3 a.m. at the Groove Lounge, the police said. Patrons spilled outside the club, and witnesses said they heard several gunshots. The victim, Luis Ruiz, 24, of Clinton Hill, a single father who worked in
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Killed Outside Lounge

body: A Brooklyn man who was arrested Sunday on drunken-driving charges near the scene of a hit-and-run accident that killed a 13-year-old boy riding a bicycle was charged yesterday with vehicular manslaughter, the police said. They said that the boy, Anthony Delgado of Brooklyn, was struck just after midnight on Sunday at the intersection of Palmetto
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Driver Charged In Bicycle Fatality

body: Most humor sites begin when some smart-aleck at an old media company begins nagging: ''We have to launch a more robust entertainment vertical, guys.'' But Black20 has a cool creation myth. The story is so suspiciously cool, it puts Black20.com closer to an enterprise like ''Ocean's Eleven'' or ''Easy Rider'' than to a technobabble online initiative
title: SCREENS; Satire With the Blessing of Lady Luck Herself

body: A 13-year-old boy riding a borrowed bicycle was struck and killed by a sport utility vehicle as he ventured into a Brooklyn intersection just after midnight yesterday, according to the police and his family. The driver of the S.U.V. fled the scene, the police said. The boy, Anthony Delgado, was pedaling home from another friend's baptism party
title: Hit-and-Run at Brooklyn Intersection Kills Boy Riding a Bike

author: Jocko Weyland is the author of ''The Answer Is Never: A Skateboarder's History of the World.''
body: WHEN is a bicycle not like other bicycles? To begin with, when it has no brakes, or at least no visible brakes, or possibly just a front brake. That means you can't ride this bike very well on your first try, and certainly not very gracefully, easily or safely. The rear cog is bolted directly to the hub, so that whenever the vehicle is in motion,
title: Unstoppable

body: HARRY McNALLY and Nick Poe are arty, neo-Bohemian 20-somethings, the sort of people who can't afford to rent in downtown Manhattan anymore. But they manage to live in the heart of SoHo because they rent the apartment where Mr. McNally spent much of his childhood. His father, Keith, who owns quintessential downtown restaurants like Balthazar, Pastis
title: HABITATS/SoHo; A 22-Year Lifetime on Thompson Street

body: Firefighters wear them with pride, on their sleeves, a variation on the blue uniform that distinguishes one assignment from another. Some are faded, even blackened: arm patches that identify each house, each company, as unique. The firefighters of Engine 218 in Brooklyn are the Bushwick Bomberos, their symbol a firefighter with water hoses in
title: Firefighters' Symbol of Pride Gets Image Upgrade

body: It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single person in New York in possession of a sunlit day must be in want of a companion. Just ask Eric Jacobov, 24, a commercial building developer, who strolled with two friends in Central Park yesterday. ''I like spring,'' he said, lighting a cigarette and peering at sunbathers in the Sheep Meadow.
title: As City Begins Spring Stir, Romance Is in the Air

body: Around Town Museums and Sites AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY Central Park West and 79th Street. Through April 6, 2008, ''Beyond,'' an exhibition of more than 30 large-format photographs of Earth's planetary neighbors, in the museum's Imax Gallery. Through Jan. 6, ''The Unknown Audubons: Mammals of North America,'' a display of more than 40
title: SPARE TIMES: April 20 - April 26

body: To the Editor: ''Don't Discard the Bottle Bill'' (editorial, April 8) is unrealistic. Adding beverages is a good idea, in theory. People discard their containers because they're too much trouble to redeem. Things need to change before adding new beverages. Try to redeem containers, you end up waiting behind three people, collecting bottles for a
title: Don't Be Fooled By the Bottle Bill

body: MARNIE STERN, 30, played her electric guitar in the basement performance space of Cake Shop on Ludlow Street last month. This would have been a familiar occurrence if she were knocking out punk rock bar chords, or plucking an airy folk melody. But both of Ms. Stern's hands moved swiftly along the fretboard like pale spiders, her fingertips
title: MUSIC; Guitar Heroes, Make That Heroines, In Indie Rock

body: FIRST came chaos, a neighbor said, then death. The nine deaths Wednesday following a fire in an apartment in the Highbridge section of the Bronx included eight children, among them twins just 7 months old. The cruelty of loss seemed especially shocking in an era when the number of fires in the city continues to decline, and when, in general, the
title: URBAN TACTICS; New York Tinderbox

body: The phone rang in Moises Alou's apartment in Montreal. It was late, creeping toward midnight, and his wife, Austria, six months pregnant with their second child, was sitting beside him, watching a movie. She answered the phone. On the other end was an aunt, calling from Brooklyn. The connection was poor, and it was just as well, for Austria could
title: BASEBALL; In Left Field, Remembering

body: A 16-year-old was fatally stabbed about 2 a.m. yesterday during a party at a Masonic temple in Brooklyn, the police said, and moments later two men who had been involved in a dispute there were shot two blocks away. The teenager, Shaquail Sanders, was on the dance floor when he was stabbed twice in the chest. He was dead on arrival at Woodhull
title: Youth Killed In Brooklyn; 2 Men Hurt In Shooting

body: The City Department of Homeless Services yesterday announced a citywide expansion of its HomeBase program, which now serves people in six neighborhoods who are at risk of becoming homeless. The program, begun in September 2004, has provided job training, housing relocation and legal and financial services to 6,300 families and adults and 8,200
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City To Expand Housing Program

body: Long before Joe DiMaggio joined the Yankees, the other Joe D was in pinstripes. ''There was nothing better than wearing the Yankee uniform,'' said Joe DiGangi, the team's bullpen catcher from 1933 to 1941. ''To have spent summer days with Babe Ruth and Lou Gehrig, to have known men like Bill Dickey, Tony Lazzeri, Phil Rizzuto and Joe DiMaggio,
title: BASEBALL; Pinstripe Memories: Joe D From Brooklyn Was Living a Dream

body: His build is slight and he stands only 5-foot-6, but Kyle Sierra grew up playing basketball on the courts of East New York, Brooklyn, and is tough enough to take the physical pounding that passes for high school basketball in the city. But late last year, when he learned that the basketball team at his school, Paul Robeson High, had been suspended
title: A Team Feared by Rivals Now Sits Idle, and Angry

body: Subways future and subways past seemed to collide on a recent morning at the Jefferson Street station on the L line in Bushwick, Brooklyn. New electronic signs on the platforms showed how many minutes a person would have to wait until the next train: at this moment it was eight minutes for a Canarsie-bound train and four minutes for a
title: How Long Till Next Train? The Answer Is Up in Lights

body: The Downtown Brooklyn shopping plaza formerly known as the Albee Square Mall will soon undergo yet another incarnation: It will be razed, rebuilt at triple the size and topped with a high-rise with offices and a thousand apartments, its prospective new owners said yesterday. The mall is being sold to a partnership of developers for about $125
title: Deal Would Triple the Size of the Albee Square Mall in Brooklyn and Add a High-Rise

body: They are a fixture across New York City, giving shoppers a welcoming smile and a helping hand as they assist cashiers in packing everything from apples to zucchinis. In many supermarkets, managers treat these baggers as volunteers, not paying them wages and making them rely on tips. But now, in a new front in the wage-and-hour wars, many baggers
title: Long Treated as Volunteers, Tips-Only Supermarket Baggers Take Up Fight for Hourly Wage

body: Sally Mae Jenkins is full of stories. In a breathless rasp, she recalls traipsing through the woods of her native South Carolina, running from snakes and getting into dicey escapades with her 13 brothers and sisters. Then she talks of having a daughter at 17, only to lose her 25 years later. Each reverie is delivered in her thick-as-molasses
title: The Neediest Cases; A Warm Coat for a Woman With Endless Stories to Tell

body: The bugler sounded his call. A bone-numbing chill rushed through the paddock, tearing into the jockey's silks and biting at his skin. It was the ninth and last race on Saturday, a frigid afternoon at Aqueduct, and the only people left in the stands and on the track were those down to their last chance. ''Go get 'em, Frankie,'' someone yelled from
title: Fame Waits at the Wire

body: A top New York City schools superintendent abruptly retired after investigators' found that he had had an affair with a subordinate, city education officials said yesterday. On Friday, the city's Education Department announced the retirement of the superintendent, Reyes Irizarry, 56, who oversaw more than 100 schools and more than 100,000 students
title: School Official Steps Down After Inquiry

body: A man falls from a subway platform, a toddler tumbles from a fire escape -- two quintessential New York nightmares. Three men race to the rescue. One jumps onto the tracks to save the fallen man. The two others position themselves to catch the child. New Yorkers helping New Yorkers: How quintessentially New York is that? The reflexive willingness
title: What Would You Do?; New Yorkers Doubt That Their Response To a Crisis Would Be, 'Hey, Not My Problem'
